Monoid
A set $M$ with a law of composition $\sigma: M \times M \longrightarrow M$ is called a monoid if $\sigma$ is associative and $M$ admits a unit element with respect to $\sigma$.
Group Homomorphism

Let $G, G^{\'prime}$ be monoids with corresponding unit elements $e$ and $e^{\'prime}$. A monoid homomorphism $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\'prime}$ is a map $\varphi$ from $G$ to $G^{\'prime}$ such that (i) $\varphi(e)=e^{\'prime}$, (ii) $\varphi(a b)=\varphi(a) \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in G$. Furthermore, if $G, G^{\'prime}$ are groups, $\varphi$ is called a group homomorphism.
Coefficient of a Polynomial

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.
Ideal

Let $R$ be a ring. A subset $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ is called an ideal in $R$ if: (i) $\mathfrak{a}$ is an additive subgroup of $R$. (ii) For any $r \in R$ and $a \in \mathfrak{a}$, it holds that $ra \in \mathfrak{a}$.
Euclidean function
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.
Canonical Homomorphism
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
Rank of an A-module
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
Algebra over a Ring

An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.
Separable extension
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.
Element of a Set
An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.
Map/Function
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A group homomorphism is a specific type of monoid homomorphism, and the definition of a monoid homomorphism requires the concept of a monoid.
An ideal is defined within the context of a ring, so the concept of a ring is necessary to define an ideal.
A canonical homomorphism is a specific type of ring homomorphism, and the definition of a ring homomorphism requires the concept of a ring.
An algebra over a ring is defined as a ring homomorphism, so the concept of a ring is necessary to define an algebra over a ring.
A splitting field of a polynomial is defined in terms of a field, so the concept of a field is necessary to define a splitting field.
A separable extension is defined in terms of fields, so the concept of a field is necessary to define a separable extension.
A map/function is a fundamental concept that is used in the definition of many other concepts, including group homomorphisms, canonical homomorphisms, and algebras over a ring.
